awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Examining and applying robot sociality to enhance intergroup human-robot interaction
awd_abstract_narration:
Robots are becoming increasingly common enhancements in people's lives. They tutor students, help around the house, work in factories, and more. For robotic technology to be the most helpful, it is important to learn how people best interact with it. In this project, the researchers apply theory of social psychology and group dynamics to improve human-robot teaming. Previous research has shown that humans work better with robots that they view as teammates (called 'ingroup') than robots that they view as opponents (called 'outgroup'). However, ingroup and outgroup are social categories, and it is not known how social a robot must behave to benefit from ingroup favoritism. Conversely, it is uncertain if nonsocial robots can avoid the drawbacks of being viewed as outgroup members. In this project, researchers will develop the understanding of these critical factors and apply them to real-world human-robot teams, such as for construction. This will promote the progress of psychological science, demonstrating how far principles of psychological group dynamics extend to nonsocial agents and when these principles break down. The results will lead to robot design recommendations to improve human-robot teaming. For example, this research might indicate that humans and machine-like robots can work most efficiently and smoothly together when the robots behave uniformly.

To examine intergroup human-robot interaction, the researchers will set up cooperative and competitive contexts to elicit group effects and determine how social the robots must be to be treated like ingroup or outgroup members (Study 1). Then the researchers will determine if social group principles, such as entitativity (cohesiveness) of robot groups, affect interactions with them even when robots are nonsocial (paralleling factory-created construction robots in the real world; Study 2). Because human groups will interact with robots (e.g., family members interacting with a home robot, a construction crew), the researchers will examine how human group type (e.g., friend, coworker) affects responses toward the robots (Study 3). Because groups are more competitive than individuals, the researchers will examine one-on-one contact with robots before group interaction with them to reduce prejudice against them (Study 4). Finally, the researchers will apply their research findings from Studies 1-4 to the real world and the introduction of construction robots with their collaborators from the College of Engineering (Study 5). This research will lay the foundation for understanding group dynamics in human-robot interaction. Based on the findings, the researchers will provide design recommendations about what robot form and intragroup behavior will be best suited for intergroup interaction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

Robots are becoming increasingly prevalent to enhance people’s lives. They tutor students, help around the house, work in factories, and more. For robotic technology to be the most helpful, it is important to understand human-robot interaction (HRI), including how people best interact with robots. In this project, I lead my team to apply theory of social psychology and group dynamics to improve human-robot teaming. Previous research had shown that humans work better with robots that they view as teammates (i.e., ingroup) than robots that they view as opponents (i.e., outgroup). The research from this grant advanced these findings, indicating that people respond to more anthropomorphic (humanlike) robots more similarly to how they respond to people, compared to more machinelike robots. This means that more anthropomorphic robots receive more of the benefits from being perceived as ingroup members to humans, but also more drawbacks from being perceived as outgroup members of humans. These effects also depend on culture, with participants from more collectivistic cultures or who think of themselves more in terms of group memberships (i.e., have more collective self-cognitions), compared to participants from individualistic cultures or who think of themselves in terms of individual traits (i.e., private self-cognitions), accepting more robots into their ingroups.

We also extended findings about how human groups respond to robots. Our series of both in-lab and real-world studies shows that when human groups are cohesive, they display more group polarization than diverse human groups. This results in human groups being more interactive with robots if they can freely choose whether or not to interact with the robots (e.g., a mall guidance robot that participants can choose to approach or not), but less interacted with the robots if it is a loose requirement interact with the robots (e.g., in a laboratory study; a robot receptionist that participant must approach if they wish to dine at a restaurant). This shows critical differences between individuals and groups, with groups responding in a more polarized or exaggerated manner than individuals (either positive or negative). It also shows vital differences between group responses in the labs versus real-world contexts. We further found that groups can be especially helpful in learning peoples’ perceptions of automated technology such as a semi-autonomous car; groups provided more feedback than individuals, especially as they talked to each other about their perceptions of the vehicle. Thus, using groups to examine robots can help researchers more clearly understand what people like and need improved about the robot.

Broader impacts

This work advances our understanding of how to improve acceptance of robots and team collaboration with robots. Because groups polarize more toward robots that individuals do, it is critical that especially when groups may interact with the robots, people are given the option of whether or not to interact with the robots. This will increase robot acceptance because people who are interested in the robot will gather together to interact with it and have an even more positive experience than individuals interacting with it. Conversely, people who are not interested in interacting with the robot will not be forced to have an interaction which will polarize to be more negative. These people may then later have more positive experiences with robots; if they come later with a group that is interested in the robot, it can cause them to polarize in a more positive direction of accepting the robot.

We have disseminated results of our studies. We currently have six publications in journals or peer-reviewed conferences that are either published or about to be published, along with four papers under review and three more in preparation. We have published at top venues including Computer-Supported Cooperative Work and Frontiers in Psychology. We have also shared our findings with middle and high school students through events with the Museum of Nature and Science, and we ran a workshop to teach these children how to design and program robot interaction.

Through this project, I have advanced education of new HRI researchers through running an international workshop on improving HRI study design. At this workshop, we gathered top researchers at to mentor newer researchers on concrete study ideas. Workshop participants indicated on surveys that they greatly benefited from the workshop. We also published the results of the workshop to (a) share how to run a successful workshop like this to advance the knowledge and skill in the international HRI community and (b) spread knowledge of the “lessons learned” in the workshop to help newer researchers understand concepts that are not commonly taught in textbooks but that researchers tend to learn from experience. This will advance the skill and quality of HRI research in the coming years.

Further, we especially worked with women and minority groups throughout the research on these projects, educating 51 students (2/3 women, 3/5 underrepresented minority students).
